column1: The name Ennis comes from the Irish word "Inis"
column2: meaning "island". This name relates to an island formed between two courses of the River Fergus on which the Franciscan Friary was built. The past of Ennis is closely associated with the O'Brien dynasty
column3: who were descendants of Brian Boru. In the 12th century
column6: left their seat of power in Limerick and built a royal residence at Clonroad on what was then an island. In 1240
column7: King Donnchadh O'Brien ordered the construction of an extensive church which he later donated to the Franciscans. In the centuries that followed there was great activity. The Friary was expanded and students came in great flocks to study at the theological college. The Friars
column8: who were free to move about
column9: met the spiritual needs of the local population. It was a religious centre until the Dissolution of the Monasteries.

column1: Ennis never had town walls and became a location for merchants from Limerick when Catholics were forbidden to reside in the walled towns by the Penal Laws
column2: and much of its past prosperity is attributable to this influx. It became a thriving market town in the late 18th century and this expansion continued unabated throughout the 19th century
column3: except the period after the Famine c. 1850.

column2: a number of landmark structures were constructed
column3: including the Mill and Courthouse. The town contains a number of old military barracks
column4: most notably the Old Military Barracks on the Kilrush road. Many locals served in the British Army in the First World War. The Clare Road and Clonroad areas contain terraced cottages built in the early 20th century to house soldiers. On Station Road

column1: Ennis was governed by a town council from around the 17th century onwards
column2: before the Local Government Reform Act 2014 effectively dissolved this with the creation of the Ennis Municipal District under the authority of Clare County Council. Politically
column3: Ennis has always been considered a Fianna Fáil stronghold. However
column5: the party was reduced to just one member out of nine on Ennis Town Council. A monument to Éamon de Valera
column6: founder of the party and former President of Ireland
column7: stands outside Ennis Courthouse.The River Fergus runs through the middle of Ennis
column8: and is a well-known trout and salmon fishery. At one time
column9: small sailing boats made their way up river from the Shannon and berthed in the centre of the town at Woodquay. This area of the town along with Parnell Street and Mill Road was routinely susceptible to flooding
column10: but the flood defence system put an end to the event in Parnell Street and the Mill Road areas
column11: although in November 2009 other parts of the town experienced severe flooding. A new pedestrian bridge
column13: was built over the river Fergus in June 2009.

column1: Clare became a county under the rule of Elizabeth I and Ennis was chosen as its capital by the Earls of Thomond because of its central location and great influence. Ennis received a grant to hold fairs and markets in 1610 and some years later a Charter for a Corporation with a Provost
column2: Free Burgesses
column3: Commonalty and a Town Clerk.Ennis continued to expand in the following centuries
column4: mainly as a market town and later as a manufacturing and distributing centre. Many commodities were conveyed by river to Clarecastle for shipment abroad.Ennis is a historically important market town. The market square is still home to market stalls on each Saturday through the year
column5: although with the rise in the town's commercial retail sector it has shifted from agricultural produce to mainly textiles and home hardware. The market also has an organic farming element.The town centre consists of medieval narrow streets and laneways
column6: overshadowed by structures built over the last thousand years. Of the main thoroughfares
column11: are one way. The Cathedral of Saint Peter and Saint Paul is on the fringe of the old town centre.

column1: Ennis has been a centre for Irish Traditional Music
column2: and since 1974 has hosted the Fleadh Nua in late May each year
column3: the second-largest traditional music festival in Ireland. There are other traditional festivals held in the town as well such as the Ennis Trad Festival held annually in November.

column2: Ennis is served by both bus and rail links to all major cities and towns in Ireland. The main bus depot is adjacent to the town's train station and both are about one kilometre from the town centre. Ennis railway station is on the Clon Road toward the east of the town
column3: which links to the main N18 in either direction.

column1: Twenty rail services per day are now provided to and from Limerick

column3: to Tuam and Claremorris
column5: is subject to budget review.Ennis was formerly the starting point of the West Clare Railway
column6: a narrow-gauge railway which ran from Ennis to Ennistymon
column7: Milltown Malbay and onwards to the towns and villages along the West Clare coastline. Trains ran from the same railway station as still used by mainline Irish railway services. The line was CIÉ's last narrow-gauge railway and finally closed in 1961

column2: Ennis became Ireland's first and only Information Age Town. The town was greatly enhanced by the project's IR£15 million investment
column3: which saw 4200 computers provided to residents
column4: a computer lab for every school and every primary school classroom been provided with a computer. Elderly residents were given the chance to become computer users also as a result. The project also gave Ennis Ireland's first high-speed ISDN line infrastructure
column5: which connected all the town's businesses together. Ennis was also used as a test site for VISA Cash
column6: which allowed users to top up a Chip and PIN card with petty cash and purchase goods in local stores. Funding for the project ran out in 2000.
